statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Portland 72, Cascade 46
article.story: PORTLAND, Ore. (AP) -- Reserves Ethan Niedermeyer and Robin Smeulders scored 13 points each to lead Portland to an easy 72-46 victory over Cascade College Saturday night. Portland starting forward Sherrard Watson added 12 points despite playing only 16 minutes and Jared Stohl, another reserve, contributed 10. Erving Adams led Cascade with 13 points, but he hit only 4 of 17 shots from the field. Portland (5-8) committed 21 turnovers, but the Pilots overcame that by hitting 53 percent of their shots. Niedermeyer went 5 for 5 while Watson was 5 of 6 and Smeulders finished 5 of 8. Cascade, an unheralded NAIA school located in east Portland, got off to a bad start by missing its first 13 shots of the game. The Thunderbirds' first points of the game came on a pair of free throws by Tayo Cotton at the 13:12 mark. That stopped a 12-0 run by Portland. The Pilots pushed their advantage to 22-4 before Cascade was able to get its offense in gear. The Thunderbirds sealed their fate by going more than eight minutes without a point during the early stages of the second half. The Pilots reeled off 13 points during that stretch to make the score 50-18. The Pilots seemed to relax a bit for most of the final 10-plus minutes. Cascade responded by going on a 23-18 run, but Portland still led 68-44 after that spurt. The Thunderbirds (5-9) made only 26 percent of their field goal attempts and they hit just 19 percent of their three-point tries. They were also out-rebounded 50-23 by the Pilots. Portland's Luke Sikma was the leading rebounder with 13. He also hit 4 of 5 shots for eight points.
